questions.question: 1. Which of these best describes an array?

answers.a: A data structure that shows a hierarchical behaviour
answers.b: Container of objects of similar types
answers.c: Container of objects of mixed types

explanations.a: Incorrect. The data structure that shows hierarchical behaviour is a tree, not an array.
explanations.b: Correct. An array is a container for objects of similar types.
explanations.c: Incorrect. A list can store mixed types, but an array cannot.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Only one of the mentioned answers describes an array.

questions.question: 2. What is the time complexity of insertion at any point in an array?

explanations.a: Correct. Inserting at any point in an array requires shifting elements, which is O(N).
explanations.b: Incorrect. Insertion in an array is not O(N^2).
explanations.c: Incorrect. Insertion in an array is not O(NLogN).
explanations.d: Incorrect. Option a is the correct answer.

questions.question: 3. Which of the following is an incorrect declaration of a one-dimensional array?

explanations.a: Incorrect. This is a valid declaration of an integer array.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This is a valid declaration of a character array.
explanations.c: Correct. This is not a valid array declaration in C/C++.
explanations.d: Incorrect. This is a valid declaration of an integer array.

questions.question: 4. In a singly-linked list, each node contains a minimum of two fields. If one field is the data field to store the data, then the second field is _______.

explanations.a: Incorrect. The correct term is 'pointer to next node'.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Each node does not point to the head node.
explanations.c: Correct. Each node points to the next node in the list.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Option c is the correct answer.

questions.question: 5. What would be the asymptotic time complexity to add a tail element and to find an element in the linked list?

explanations.a: Correct. Both adding a tail element and finding an element in a singly linked list are O(n).
explanations.b: Incorrect. Adding a tail element is O(n) unless you maintain a tail pointer.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Finding an element is O(n) in a singly linked list.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Both operations are not O(1) in a singly linked list.

questions.question: 6. Why do we need pointers in a linked list but not in an array?

answers.a: Linked list can store any type of data
answers.b: Data is not stored in contiguous locations in linked list
answers.c: Array can only store elements of same type of data

explanations.a: Incorrect. The need for pointers is not because of data type flexibility.
explanations.b: Correct. Pointers are needed because linked list nodes are not stored in contiguous memory.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This is a property of arrays, not the reason for pointers in linked lists.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Option b is the correct answer.
